trial_identification.studytitle: Production and utilization of lactate in an intensive care patient population
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Description of lactate kinetics in ICU patients using a bolus injection of 13C-labeled lactate - an experimental open-label non-randomized clinical trial

conditions.healthcondition: Mixed Intensive Care Unit patients with single or multiple organ failure

interventions.interventions: Each ICU patient will receive a single bolus dose of 13C-labeled lactate (2.7mg/kg body weight). Existing arterial and venous lines will be used. Blood samples will be drawn at t=0 and then every two minutes during the first hour and every fifth minute for the second hour (t=2,4,6...56,58,60,65,70...110,115,120)
interventions.comparator: No control group will be recruited but results will be compered to previous trials on healthy volunteers.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Rate of appearance of lactate in blood.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Samples are taken at baseline and then throughout the first two hours after injection of 13C-lactate bolus is given. Initially every two minutes during the first hour and then every fifth minute during the second hour (t=0,2, 4, 6 .... 56, 58, 60, 65, 70...110, 115, 120)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Rate of disappearance of lactate in blood
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Samples are taken at baseline and then throughout the first two hours after injection of 13C-lactate bolus is given. Initially every two minutes during the first hour and then every fifth minute during the second hour (t=0,2, 4, 6 .... 56, 58, 60, 65, 70...110, 115, 120)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Correlation between absolute levels of lactate in blood and rate of appearance of lactate in blood will be evaluated as a secondary outcome
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Samples are taken at baseline and then throughout the first two hours after injection of 13C-lactate bolus is given. Initially every two minutes during the first hour and then every fifth minute during the second hour (t=0,2, 4, 6 .... 56, 58, 60, 65, 70...110, 115, 120)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Patients treated in the ICU who have an existing, functioning arterial and venous lines - Informed consent to participate (can be given by next of kin when appropriate)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Unwillingness to participate, Unable to obtain informer consent. Terminal liver insufficiency.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: After linear approximation of the decay in 13C-lactate enrichment for each subject, individual kinetics will be derived and means compared in group and to previous series in healthy volunteers.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Karolinska University Hospital Dept of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care K32 141 86 Stockholm Sweden

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Karolinska University Hospital Dept of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care K32 141 86 Stockholm Sweden
CLINTEC, dept of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care K32 141 86 Stockholm Swedenv

ethicsAndSummary.summary: In order to describe lactate metabolism in critically ill patients our group has designed a simple, minimally invasive protocol in healthy volunteers. In our current study we aim to use this protocol in a mixed ICU population. Briefly patients will be recruited after informed consent (from next of kin when appropriate). After this baseline samples will be drawn and a bolus dose of 13C-labeled lactate (2.7mg/kg) will be given. Blood samples will be drawn over two hours (no more than 100 ml all together), samples will be frozen and analyzed for lactate concentration and 13C-enrichment. An interim analysis will be conducted after the first 6 patients. Data will be collected from electronical charting systems.
